results.title: Play It Again I: Games Collection
results.brief_description:
The Play It Again I project aimed to create a playable history of Australasian video games for industry, community and research purposes, by building on existing research into the history of Beam Software and their games from the 1980s.

This collection comprises physical games donated to ACMI for the project, audio captures and game emulation files - some created at ACMI as part of the project research and some harvested from external web repositories.

The multi-faceted project brought multidisciplinary expertise to bear on the areas of collections, preservation, accessibility, fan knowledge, and the telling of histories about Australia’s digital game history.

The project was undertaken by ACMI in partnership with Flinders University, University of Melbourne, The New Zealand Film Archive, Berlin Computerspiele Museum, and the Research Trust of Victoria University of Wellington. It was funded via the Australian Research Council (ARC) Linkage Projects scheme, which funds collaborative projects between University researchers and Partner Organisations.

The project was completed in 2015.

results.title: Gaps
results.brief_description:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. ‘Gaps’ embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship - or ‘gaps’ - between self and other through speech, movement and dance.
Rosetzky’s collaborators on ‘Gaps’ include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed ‘How to Feel’ 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.
Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.
The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period. Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

One of Australia’s finest video artists, David Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. Gaps embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship – or ‘gaps’ – between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.
description_for_label:
One of Australia’s finest video artists, David Rosetzky’s captivating works have been exhibited widely throughout Australia and internationally. Gaps embodies Rosetzky’s ongoing exploration of personal identity and the relationship – or ‘gaps’ – between self and other through speech, movement and dance.

Rosetzky’s collaborators on Gaps include choreographer and performer Stephanie Lake, (who also choreographed How to Feel, 2011) co-writer Anna Zagala, and performers, Jessie Oshodi, Lee Serle, Rani Pramesti and Dimitri Baveas.

Drawing from material Rosetzky gathered conducting interviews with his cast, this new work is an oblique survey of the transition from rehearsal to performance, in both art and life.

The artist’s process involved in-depth workshopping of the material with the performers, who come from acting and dance disciplines. Lake’s choreography, which integrates naturalistic and stylised movements, was also developed with input from the cast and Rosetzky during this rehearsal period.

Long time collaborator David Franzke provides the sound design.

production_dates.notes:
Co-commissioned by ACMI and Carriageworks (Sydney).
David Rosetzky: Gaps will be a free exhibition at ACMI from 5 August 2014 to 8 February 2015.
The co-commission of Gaps by ACMI and Carriageworks has been assisted by the Australian Government through the Australian Council for the Arts, its arts funding and advisory body.

results.title: Shaun Tan's The Lost Thing: From book to film. The Interviews
results.creator_credit: Richard Greenhalgh, Kim Montgomery and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Set in a city overrun by bureaucracy, Shaun Tan’s picture book ‘The Lost Thing’ tells the story of a boy who befriends a strange creature that doesn’t appear to fit in any of the available pigeon holes.
Melbourne-based production company Passion Pictures Australia invited Shaun to direct an animated version of ‘The Lost Thing’, and several years later, the Oscar®-winning short film emerged.
The ACMI exhibition ‘Shaun Tan’s The Lost Thing: From book to film’(showing in Gallery Two from 16th July 2013 to 19th January 2014), features Shaun’s exquisite original drawings and working sketches alongside exclusive footage of the animators and sound artists, demonstrating how the drawings were brought to life on screen with movement, sound effects, music and narration.
These eight interview segments are each based on a particular production process in the making of ‘The Lost Thing’.
The eight segments feature interviews with Shaun Tan (writer/co director), Sophie Byrne (producer), Tom Bryant (3D artist), Leo Baker (animator), John Kassab (sound designer) and Michael Yezerski (composer).
In addition to the interviews, there is a wealth of ‘behind-the-scenes’ footage, rough drafts of designs and animation wireframes from the very early stages of production.

results.brief_description: ‘The Lost Thing’ production team talk about their approach to creating the character of ‘The Boy’ and using the book as a guide when designing the character and creating the boy’s movements and associated sounds.
